channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Letter From Europe: Recasting France’s Role in Africa
item.description: The Central African Republic is the newest focus of an effort by President François Hollande to revive his nation’s influence in Africa.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A French armored vehicle patrolled Bangui, capital of the Central African Republic, on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran Invites Inspectors to Nuclear Site
item.description: The invitation to the International Atomic Energy Agency came five days after Tehran struck a landmark nuclear deal with world powers.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: November 28
item.description: A cauliflower field in Kolkata, West Bengal.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Women working in a cauliflower field in Kolkata, West Bengal.

item.title: India Ink: Andhra Pradesh Heaves Sigh of Relief as Cyclone Lehar Becomes Deep Depression
item.description: The storm is still expected to bring heavy rain that could add to the damage caused by two previous cyclones over the past eight weeks.
item.dc:creator: By SRIRAM KARRI
item.media:description: Fishermen in Gopalpur, Odisha, on Wednesday walking homeward after a cyclone alert in the area. Odisha and Andhra Pradesh are expected to receive heavy rainfall with the coming of Lehar.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Not-So-Festive Season
item.description: Year-end parties were lavish and held at five-star hotels last year, but with President Xi Jinping’s anticorruption drive in full force, state-owned enterprises and government agencies are scaling back.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: A waitress prepares a table in a private dining room at a restaurant in Beijing. High-end restaurants and hotels have reported sharp declines in business under President Xi Jinping's anti-extravagance campaign.

item.title: Japan and South Korea Fly Military Planes in Zone Set by China
item.description: Japan, locked in a territorial dispute with China, and South Korea sent planes to patrol the airspace without informing China.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: A Japanese patrol plane, pictured in 2011, flying over the disputed islands in the East China Sea.

item.title: Thai Leader Survives Vote as Protests Continue
item.description: The number of antigovernment protesters appeared to drop sharply Thursday as Thailand’s prime minister, Yingluck Shinawatra, urged that the demonstrations cease.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters gathered outside the Defense Ministry in Bangkok on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Corruption Scandal Hits One of China’s Top Universities
item.description: A top administrator at a prestigious Chinese university in Beijing was accused of trying to flee the country after he came under investigation in a corruption case.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students in front of the library at Renmin University, where a senior administrator is reported to be under investigation in a corruption case.

item.title: India Ink: Managing Editor of Newsmagazine Resigns Amid Sexual Assault Controversy
item.description: In her resignation letter, Shoma Chaudhury defended her handling of a complaint by a staffer who had accused the editor in chief of sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Protesters burning a photograph of Tarun Tejpal, founder of newsmagazine Tehelka, at a demonstration in New Delhi on Nov. 22.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Yao Ming on Third Year as a College Student
item.description: Yao Ming is less than two years away from fulfilling his promise to his parents that he would go to college, a common but seldom realized dream for Chinese athletes.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: The retired N.B.A. star is majoring in economics at Jiao Tong University in Shanghai.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Eased Rules May Affect Trials of 2 Kenyans
item.description: President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya and his deputy, William Ruto, have pleaded not guilty to charges that they were responsible for deadly violence after the 2007 elections.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Behind the Chinese-Pakistani Nuclear Deal
item.description: A deal in which China will help build nuclear plants in Karachi should help ease Pakistan’s chronic power supply problems, but it has also raised alarms about nuclear security.
item.category: German Marshall Fund of the United States
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: 14 Female Protesters Receive 11-Year Sentences
item.description: In addition, seven girls ranging from 15 to 17 years old were also sentenced to an indeterminate term at a juvenile facility for joining the protest.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MAYY EL SHEIKH

item.title: Mystery of Missing Mushrooms Leaves French Blaming Roma
item.description: Competition between established French companies and outside mushroom pickers has brought with it darker undercurrents of hostility and discrimination.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Nanda Gonzague for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some French mushroom pickers, disappointed by low yields, say that foreigners are at fault.

item.title: China’s Move Puts Airspace in Spotlight
item.description: Who has the right to fly where is an issue that has created confusion, and danger, in places affected by territorial disputes.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and MATTHEW L. WALD

item.title: After Challenges, China Appears to Backpedal on Air Zone
item.description: China said it would respond to foreign aircraft in its new air defense zone according to “how big the threat” was, after a flight by American B-52s through the airspace.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The disputed islands in the East China Sea are known as the Diaoyu by China and as the Senkaku by Japan.

item.title: Deadly Accident at Stadium Raises Worry on Brazil’s World Cup Aims
item.description: A construction crane collapse at the site of the São Paulo stadium where the 2014 World Cup is scheduled to open puts a spotlight on increasing tensions among Brazilians about cost overruns, delays and the country’s priorities.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: A crane collapsed Wednesday at the construction site of the Arena Corinthians stadium in São Paulo, where the opening game of the 2014 World Cup is to be held.

item.title: Not for Prime Time: Music Video With Iran’s President
item.description: A music video honoring President Hassan Rouhani includes features banned on state TV.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Berlusconi Expelled From Senate in Italy After 2 Decades in Government
item.description: Silvio Berlusconi, Italy’s once-powerful former prime minister, was stripped of his seat on Wednesday, leaving him without elective office for the first time in about two decades.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi, 77, speaking to his supporters in downtown Rome on Wednesday.

item.title: The Lede: Crackdown in Egypt Fuels New Dissent
item.description: There were street protests in Egypt’s two largest cites on Wednesday, amid signs that attempts by the military-backed government to stifle dissent were fueling a backlash.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: German Rivals Reach Pact for Coalition Government
item.description: The agreement between Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative bloc and the center-left Social Democrats would introduce Germany’s first minimum wage.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel, center, with leaders from the Social Democrats and the Christian Social Union after signing a coalition contract in Berlin on Wednesday.

item.title: Dispute Over Immigration Widens Between Britain and E.U.
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron said he would institute new restrictions on migrants amid concerns about an influx of Bulgarians and Romanians next year.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron leaving 10 Downing Street in London on Wednesday.

item.title: The Lede: Kerry and Zarif Turn to Selling Nuclear Deal to Skeptics Back Home
item.description: Having reached an interim agreement to freeze Iran’s nuclear program, Secretary of State John Kerry and his Iranian counterpart, Mohammad Javad Zarif, turned their attention to selling at home.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Party Claims It Identified Top C.I.A. Spy in Pakistan
item.description: The political party of former cricket star Imran Khan apparently revealed the name in an escalation of its campaign to end American drone strikes in the country.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Grief and Heroism as Survivors Struggle in the Philippines
item.description: Acts of heroism abound in the Philippines after Typhoon Haiyan, often with a special emphasis on ensuring the survival of children.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jomar Pascua cooked food for his siblings at an elementary school in Tacloban.
